questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

 

For a patient presenting with hemodynamically unstable symptoms such as a significantly low blood pressure and a high heart rate, as indicated by a pulse of 180/min and systolic BP of 70 mmHg, immediate DC cardioversion is indicated. This procedure is critical for restoring normal heart rhythm and preventing further cardiovascular compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valsalva Maneuver: it is typically used in stable patients to attempt cardioversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) back to a normal rhythm. It is not suitable for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Adenosine: it is effective in terminating certain types of SVT by temporarily blocking the AV node but is used in stable patients. Given the patient's low BP, this is not the first-line approach.

 

Option D. Verapamil: it is a calcium channel blocker used for rate control in cases of SVT, more appropriate for stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

choices.text: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.text: As an intern in emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum (i.e., N-E-X)

 

Approximate length of nasogastric tube is 120 -125cm     

 

How to confirm correct position of NG tube:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • x-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

 

 

XIPHISTERNUM

 

Place the tip of the nasogastric tube at the tip of the nose, then measure from the nose to the ear lobe & down to the tip of the Xiphisternum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus: This measurement is too long as it typically extends beyond the stomach, potentially reaching into the intestines.

 

Option C. Mouth to ear to umbilicus: This measurement is also incorrect and typically used for other medical estimations, not for NG tube placement.

 

Option D. Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus: Similar to option B, this measurement is excessively long for proper NG tube placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting a nasogastric tube, the correct measurement to estimate the necessary tube length is from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the xiphisternum, ensuring the tube reaches the stomach properly for effective therapeutic or diagnostic use.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

Furosemide can be used in this patient. All the other drugs mentioned are avoided due to the risk of hyperkalemia.

 

Beta – blockers- interferes with beta 2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake.

 

ACE Inhibitors- inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion.

 

Angiotensin II receptors blockers (ARBS)- block AT1 receptor, decreasing in aldosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Typically avoided if there's a risk of hyperkalemia, as it can be dangerous in elevated potassium levels, potentially causing cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Being a potassium-sparing diuretic, it is contraindicated in patients with high serum potassium levels as it could exacerbate hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Enalapril: As an ACE inhibitor, it can increase potassium levels by reducing aldosterone secretion, thus inappropriate for patients already presenting with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In heart failure patients with elevated potassium levels, loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred to manage fluid overload and avoid exacerbation of hyperkalemia, unlike potassium-sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALS


Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs. The presence of both Babinski sign (an upper motor neuron sign) and absent deep tendon reflexes (a lower motor neuron sign), along with the chronic progression and lack of sensory/autonomic involvement, strongly points towards ALS.

 

Other Options:


Option A. MS: Multiple sclerosis typically involves sensory symptoms and demyelinating plaques visible on MRI, which are not described here.

 

Option C. GBS: Guillain-Barr√© Syndrome is an acute condition with a rapid onset and is primarily a lower motor neuron disease without upper motor neuron signs like the Babinski reflex.

 

Option D. Tropical spastic paraparesis: This condition is associated with HTLV-1 infection and presents predominantly with upper motor neuron signs, not the mixed signs seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALS presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive weakness, and no sensory or autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap is seen in all except? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Salicylate poisoning.

 

Metabolic acidosis can present with either a normal or elevated anion gap. Salicylate poisoning characteristically causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of organic acids like lactic acid and ketoacids. It can initially present with a respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center, followed by metabolic acidosis as the condition progresses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis): This causes a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis due to bicarbonate loss in the urine.

 

Option B. Pancreatitis: Can lead to normal anion gap acidosis if associated with diarrhea or other mechanisms leading to bicarbonate loss.

 

Option C. Severe diarrhea: Leads to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis due to significant loss of bicarbonate in stool.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neglect

 

Neglect after a stroke, often presenting as a lack of awareness of one side of the body, does not typically require direct medical treatment. While it may indicate a more severe stroke and can impact rehabilitation, many patients improve as they recover from other stroke symptoms. Therapy focuses on aiding patients in adapting to or compensating for this deficit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia: Must be treated to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option B. Spasticity: Requires management with medications (baclofen, tizanidine) or physical therapy to improve mobility and reduce discomfort.

 

Option C. Fever: Should be treated promptly as it can exacerbate brain injury and worsen outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Area F: Positioned in the lower left part of the diagram, which corresponds to higher PCO2 and a pH less than 7.35. This area represents Acute Respiratory Acidosis due to an increase in CO2, causing a drop in blood pH.
  • Area C: Positioned in the upper right part of the diagram, which corresponds to lower PCO2 and a pH greater than 7.45. This area represents Acute Respiratory Alkalosis caused by a decrease in CO2, increasing blood pH.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal muscular atrophy

 

Tongue fasciculations are indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion, often associated with disorders that affect the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord or the motor neurons in the brainstem.

 

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA): This condition is characterized by the degeneration of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and motor nuclei in the lower brainstem. This degeneration leads to muscle weakness and atrophy, including the muscles of the tongue, resulting in tongue fasciculations. SMA is divided into several types based on the age of onset and severity, but fasciculations are a common feature across these types.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guillain-Barre syndrome: This is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy that primarily affects the peripheral nerves. It does not typically cause fasciculations, as it is more associated with rapidly progressive weakness and areflexia.

 

Option C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: This is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. It primarily affects the skeletal muscles, and while it leads to muscle weakness, it does not typically cause fasciculations.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: This is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction. It leads to fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability but does not involve lower motor neurons or cause fasciculations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tongue fasciculations are a clinical sign associated with spinal muscular atrophy due to the involvement of lower motor neurons

choices.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110 mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombolysis

 

With a BP below 185/110 mmHg, clear NCCT, and symptoms within 4.5 hours, the patient qualifies for thrombolysis, the standard treatment for acute ischemic stroke to dissolve clots and restore blood flow.

 

If the blood pressure (BP) is more than or equal to 185/110 mmHg, administer IV labetalol to lower the BP to less than 185/110 mmHg before immediately proceeding with thrombolysis. CT angiography can be performed while thrombolysis is ongoing. Start the thrombolytic agent in the CT room and simultaneously inject a bolus of contrast for the CT angiogram to check for large vessel occlusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography: CT angiography can be done simultaneously with thrombolysis but not instead of it.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is not the immediate next step when NCCT is clear.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is used to lower BP but not the primary treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


In acute ischemic stroke with BP < 185/110 and clear NCCT, thrombolysis is the next step.

questions.text: Components of the MELD (2016) score are all except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Albumin

 

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation and assesses the severity of chronic liver disease. The MELD score includes three laboratory values:

 

“CBI mnemonic = Creatinine, Bilirubin, INR are the parameters is MELD score.

 

Currently Sodium levels to the score and MELD-Na score used for prognostication. Hyponatremia associated with adverse outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Reflects the liver's ability to excrete bilirubin.

 

Option C. INR (International Normalized Ratio) for prothrombin time: Indicates the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors.

 

Option D. Creatinine: Assesses renal function, which can be compromised in liver failure. Additionally, sodium was added to the MELD score to improve its prognostic accuracy, resulting in the MELD-Na score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is not a component of the MELD score. The key components are bilirubin, creatinine, and INR, with sodium also included in the updated MELD-Na scoring system to better predict outcomes in patients with end-stage liver disease.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

questions.text:
Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. HBsAg
  2. Anti-HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBcAg
  4. HBV DNA
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): This antibody appears after the infection has been cleared or following successful vaccination. It indicates immunity to HBV. In chronic HBV infection, this antibody is not present since the surface antigen is still active.

 

Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is defined by the persistence of the surface antigen (HBsAg) for more than six months. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

 

Serological markers:

 

1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This antigen indicates that the person is infectious. It is found in the blood during acute and chronic HBV infection. The presence of HBsAg for more than six months defines chronic HBV infection.

 

3. Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): This antibody indicates previous or ongoing infection with HBV. In chronic infection, the IgG fraction of anti-HBc is usually present.

 

4. HBV DNA: The presence of HBV DNA in the blood indicates active viral replication. It is usually detectable in chronic HBV infection, although the levels can vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement

2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease

3. Resolves with desferrioxamine

4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement

5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

 

Statement 1: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is frequently seen in patients with neurological involvement due to Wilson‚Äôs disease, but it may not be present in all cases.

 

Statement 5: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is a copper deposit seen at the superior and inferior poles of the corneal Descemet's membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: While the KF ring is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, it is not solely pathognomonic because it can appear in other chronic cholestatic liver conditions.

 

Statement 3: Desferrioxamine is used for iron chelation and is not effective for copper removal in Wilson's disease. Treatment for copper overload involves agents like penicillamine or trientine.

 

Statement 4: Not all patients with hepatic involvement due to Wilson's disease will have visible KF rings, as their presence correlates more strongly with the duration and severity of copper accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.

 

Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity. 

 

Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dexamethasone

 

Dexamethasone is utilized in the treatment of hypercalcemia, particularly when induced by Vitamin D toxicity. This corticosteroid helps reduce calcium absorption from the intestine and increase calcium excretion, effectively lowering serum calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: Used primarily as an antimalarial and in autoimmune diseases, it does not play a role in managing hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Hydroxychloroquine: Similar to chloroquine, used for autoimmune disorders but not for hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Ketoconazole: An antifungal medication that can reduce corticosteroid production but is not specifically used to treat hypercalcemia caused by Vitamin D toxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone, Bisphosphonates, IV fluids, Loop diuretics, Calcitonin are used in the management of Hypercalcemia.

 

Reference - (Harrison/Endocrinology/Hypercalcemia)

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:  (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular bigeminy

 

Premature ventricular complex (PVCs)- Have following features

 

  • Broad QRS complex (>120ms) with abnormal morphology
  • Premature- i.e., occurs earlier than would be expected for the next sinus impulse
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes.
  • Usually followed by a full compensatory pause

 

PVCs often occur in repeating pattern: bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy

 

Couplet: 2 consecutive PVCs is known as couplet

 

Triplet: 3 consecutive PVCs is known as triplet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia): This condition would show a fast, regular heart rate with narrow QRS complexes; not observed here.

 

Option C. P pulmonale: This involves peaked P waves seen in leads II, III, and aVF, typically due to right atrial enlargement; not evident in this ECG.

 

Option D. Re-entrant atrial fibrillation: Would show an irregularly irregular rhythm without consistent P waves; this is not present in the ECG provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular bigeminy is identified by the presence of alternating normal sinus beats and PVCs, each PVC typically followed by a compensatory pause, creating a repeating pattern of one normal beat followed by one abnormal beat.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed:

 

AST 140 IU/L,

 

ALT 110 IU/L, and

 

GGT 500 IU/L.

 

Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lorazepam

 

The patient's liver function tests indicate elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, and GGT), suggesting potential alcoholic hepatitis or liver impairment. In such cases, choosing the appropriate benzodiazepine is crucial due to the liver's role in drug metabolism.

 

Lorazepam is a preferred benzodiazepine in patients with liver impairment for the following reasons:

 

  1. Short-acting: Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which means it has a shorter half-life and less risk of accumulation in the body compared to long-acting benzodiazepines.
  2. Minimal liver metabolism: Lorazepam undergoes minimal hepatic metabolism, which makes it safer for patients with impaired liver function. This reduces the risk of adverse effects and toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. It undergoes extensive hepatic metabolism, leading to active metabolites that can accumulate, especially in patients with liver dysfunction. This increases the risk of prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option B. Alprazolam: Alprazolam, although shorter-acting than diazepam, still undergoes significant liver metabolism. It is not as safe as lorazepam in patients with compromised liver function.

 

Option C. Clonazepam: Clonazepam is also a long-acting benzodiazepine with extensive hepatic metabolism. Like diazepam, its use in patients with liver impairment can lead to accumulation and increased risk of side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

choices.text: Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target levels despite the use of three antihypertensive agents of different classes, one of which should be a diuretic. This is because diuretics, typically thiazide diuretics, help to reduce blood volume and are effective in lowering blood pressure. Including a diuretic ensures optimal blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used but are not specifically required for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also commonly used but not specifically required for the definition.

 

Option C. Alpha blockers: Alpha blockers may be used as part of the treatment regimen but are not specifically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

questions.text: Addison's disease is commonly associated with: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoimmune adrenalitis

 

Addison's disease, primarily characterized by adrenal insufficiency, is most commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis. In this condition, the body's immune system attacks the adrenal cortex, leading to a decrease in the production of steroid hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypernephroma: Also known as renal cell carcinoma, hypernephroma is a type of kidney cancer and has no direct link to the adrenal function or Addison's disease.

 

Option C. Adrenocortical carcinoma: This is a cancer of the adrenal cortex but typically leads to excessive hormone production, associated more with Cushing's syndrome rather than Addison's disease, where there is hormone deficiency.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid: This type of cancer is associated with the thyroid gland and is related to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndrome but not directly linked to Addison's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis, where the immune system mistakenly attacks the adrenal glands, leading to insufficient production of vital hormones.

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole

 

Carbimazole is a medication used to treat hyperthyroidism and is known to cause teratogenic effects if used during pregnancy. It can lead to a rare congenital condition called aplasia cutis congenita, where the baby is born with localized areas of missing skin. The use of carbimazole, especially during the first trimester of pregnancy, is linked with this embryopathy, which highlights the importance of careful medication selection in pregnant women with thyroid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylthiouracil: Although it is an antithyroid drug, it is less commonly used and not specifically associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Option C. Levothyroxine: This is a thyroid hormone replacement and is used to treat hypothyroidism, not associated with congenital defects.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: This option appears to be a distractor as no such common drug name exists that is relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMZ, Carbimazole associated with embryonopathy in first trimester

 

Graves in Pregnancy:

 

<16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)

 

>16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)

 

Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Graves/Chap 384

choices.text: Repeat Inj. adenosine 6 mg
Inj. amiodarone 300 mg

questions.text: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchronized Cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on T phenomenon).

 

Synchronized Cardioversion is the correct choice for a hemodynamically unstable patient, as it is intended to restore normal heart rhythm without causing further cardiac risks. Synchronization ensures that the shock is delivered at a safe point in the QRS complex to prevent the induction of ventricular fibrillation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable

 

Option C. Amiodarone is used in the treatment of chronic arrhythmias and rarely for acute treatment of SVT

 

Option D. DC cardioversion technically refers to the same treatment as synchronized cardioversion in the context of unstable rhythms but the lack of specification about synchronization could imply a risk if not properly timed.

 

Synchronised cardioversion avoid possibility of R on T phenomenon.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hemodynamically unstable tachyarrhythmias where initial pharmacological interventions fail, synchronized cardioversion should be promptly employed to stabilize the patient. This technique is crucial for preventing progression to more severe complications such as cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A patient of hemophilia received multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities can be seen in a patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

Metabolic alkalosis in a patient who received multiple blood transfusions arises primarily from the metabolism of citrate, used as a preservative in stored blood products.

 

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

 

Excess citrate preservative gets converted to bicarbonate causing Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: This condition would typically result from an accumulation of acids or loss of bicarbonate, which is not a direct consequence of blood transfusion.

 

Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis: Would involve hyperventilation leading to decreased carbon dioxide levels, unrelated to transfusion effects.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Involves hypoventilation increasing carbon dioxide levels, which is also unrelated to the effects of blood transfusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic alkalosis is a potential complication of multiple or massive blood transfusions due to the metabolism of citrate preservative into bicarbonate, emphasizing the importance of monitoring electrolytes and acid-base balance during such procedures.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Delayed complications: GVHD, PTP, Infections

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was admitted complains of dyspnea. On examination he has puffy face, with engorged veins over the chest. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT thorax

 

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction, suggested by symptoms like dyspnea, facial puffiness, and engorged chest veins, along with a chest X-ray showing mediastinal enlargement, requires further detailed imaging to accurately assess the extent of the obstruction and the presence of any mediastinal masses. A CT scan of the thorax is the most appropriate next step as it provides detailed images of the chest's anatomy, helping to identify the cause of the SVC obstruction, which is crucial for planning appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total blood count with peripheral smear: While useful for general health assessments and diagnosing blood disorders, this does not directly address the structural issues seen in SVC obstruction.

 

Option C. Start cyclophosphamide: Beginning chemotherapy like cyclophosphamide would only be appropriate after a specific diagnosis of a malignancy causing the SVC obstruction, confirmed via imaging and biopsy.

 

Option D. Urgent referral to RT: Referral for radiation therapy (RT) may be necessary if a malignancy is confirmed, but it is premature without a detailed thoracic CT and biopsy if indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT thorax is critical for detailed evaluation in suspected SVC obstruction to confirm the diagnosis and guide further specific treatment, whether surgical, medical, or radiation therapy.

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements: (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
  2. Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
  3. NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
  4. All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3 correct

 

Anticoagulants are indicated for ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation. NOACs are contraindicated in patients with prosthetic valves due to a lack of evidence on their efficacy and safety in this population.

 

Other Options:

 

1. NOACs are not used for moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

4. Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are used for rate control but not universally applicable.

 

Educational Objective:


Anticoagulants are used for ischemic stroke in AF, and NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is a suitable oral medication for a diabetic patient not responding to metformin, especially when she has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer, and prefers to avoid injectable medications. Canagliflozin works by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2), which helps the kidneys excrete glucose through urine, thus lowering blood glucose levels

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: Not ideal as it has been associated with a risk of acute pancreatitis, which poses a significant risk given her medical history.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Should be avoided due to its potential link with bladder cancer, especially considering her family history.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Although effective in managing diabetes, it is not suitable as it is an injectable medication and the patient prefers to avoid injections. Moreover, it also carries a risk of pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In choosing diabetes medications for patients with specific health concerns, it's crucial to consider both the efficacy and the side-effect profile of the drug, as well as patient preferences for administration methods to ensure compliance and safety. Canagliflozin is an appropriate choice for this patient due to its oral administration and lower risk concerning her medical history.

questions.text: A young donor came to the blood bank for the first time for platelet apheresis with platelet count of 1.9L. During the course he developed paraesthesia and circumoral numbness during donation. His vitals remained stable though. ECG showed tachycardia with ST-T changes. What is the reason for his symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypocalcemia

 

Hypocalcemia occurs due to citrate. It is due to calcium binding citrate anticoagulant used to keep blood from clotting in apheresis machine.

 

Treatment for this would be to slow down the flow of device and/or giving oral calcium supplements.

 

IV calcium is only required in case of prolonged apheresis as in case of HPC collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypovolemic Shock: This would be characterized by low blood pressure and signs of systemic shock, which are not described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Seizures: Although severe hypocalcemia can lead to seizures, the description focuses on paraesthesia and numbness, common early signs of hypocalcemia, without any mention of convulsive activity.

 

Option D. Allergic Reaction: The symptoms listed are not typical of allergic reactions, which might include hives, itching, or respiratory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During platelet apheresis, monitoring for symptoms of hypocalcemia is crucial due to the use of citrate. Symptoms such as tingling, numbness, and ECG changes warrant immediate evaluation and management, typically with calcium supplementation to counteract the effects of citrate.

questions.text:
A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination, he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. Most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Opening pressure- increased
  • Proteins- mildly increased
  • Glucose ‚Äì normal
  • Lymphocytes- increased
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coxsackie

 

The CSF findings indicative of increased lymphocytes, normal glucose levels, and mildly increased protein are characteristic of viral meningitis. Coxsackie virus, a common cause of viral meningitis, often presents with these CSF findings. The typical profile of viral meningitis includes normal glucose levels, which helps differentiate it from bacterial, fungal, and tuberculous meningitis where glucose levels are often decreased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: Tuberculous meningitis typically shows low glucose, high protein, and a mixed cellular response in the CSF, which does not match the patient's CSF profile.

 

Option B. Neisseria gonorrhea: Generally causes bacterial meningitis with a different CSF profile‚Äîlow glucose, high protein, and predominantly polymorphonuclear cells.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus: Fungal meningitis also shows low glucose and is not consistent with the normal glucose levels observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A patient with renal failure develops vomiting in ICU. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.4, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L, HC03- = 24mEq/L, PaC02 = 40 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

 

Clinical history of renal failure should hint towards possibility of preexisting metabolic acidosis. Important in MCQs to always calculate AG even if ABG appears normal.

 

AG: 145-(100+24) = 21 (Normal ~12)

 

Excess unmeasured anion(H) combines with HCO3 thereby reducing the HCO3 proportionately.

 

Hence Delta ratio i.e., ΔAG(AG-12) /ΔHCO3(24-HCO3) = >2.

 

Value >2 indicate coexisting Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ABG: The pH is indeed normal, but the underlying disturbances (as reflected by an increased anion gap) indicate that the system is not normal.

 

Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: The anion gap is increased, ruling out normal anion gap acidosis.

 

Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This choice incorrectly identifies the nature of acid-base disturbances, confusing the interpretation and relationship between anion gap and bicarbonate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with renal failure and symptoms like vomiting, it's crucial to evaluate both the anion gap and changes in bicarbonate to identify complex acid-base disturbances such as the coexistence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever & altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

 

Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. However, Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains.

 

Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in with patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.

 

S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organism of community acquired bacterial meningitis. Due to the emergence of penicillin resistant and cephalosporin resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community acquired suspected bacterial meningitis should include a combination of ‚Äì

 

  • Dexamethasone
  • Third or fourth generation cephalosporin (E.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime or Cefepime)
  • Vancomycin
  • Acyclovir- HSV Encephalitis is the main differential
  • Doxycycline ‚Äìduring tick season

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: While effective against Neisseria meningitidis, it is not the first choice for empirical treatment due to broader resistance concerns and coverage needs in initial therapy settings.

 

Option C. Cefotetan and D. Cefoxitin: These are second-generation cephalosporins, which are not typically used for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis due to insufficient CNS penetration and coverage compared to third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceftriaxone is the preferred empirical therapy for meningococcal meningitis due to its effective CNS penetration, broad antibacterial coverage, and favorable dosing regimen. Immediate initiation of empirical therapy is crucial in suspected bacterial meningitis to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours and his platelet count is 14,000/¬µL. His BP is 110/70 mm of Hg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Give 4 units of platelets

2. Give plenty of oral fluids

3. Give IV fluids

4. Keep under observation

5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4

 

The patient likely has Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever, indicated by a significant rise in hematocrit, which suggests plasma leakage during the critical phase of the illness. The management strategy includes:

 

  • Statement 2. Oral fluids to maintain hydration but must be balanced to avoid fluid overload.
  • Statement 3. IV fluids are essential for the management of severe dengue to correct the plasma leakage and prevent shock.
  • Statement 4. Observation is crucial to monitor for further complications such as dengue shock syndrome.

 

Option A. 1 and 2: Platelet transfusion is generally reserved for severe bleeding or very low platelet counts (typically <10,000/¬µL without bleeding). This patient's platelet count, while low, does not alone justify transfusion without signs of active or severe bleeding.

 

Option C. 1, 2 and 4: Includes unnecessary platelet transfusion without the clear presence of severe bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Option D. 2 and 5: Discharging the patient is inappropriate given the potential for rapid deterioration during the critical phase of dengue fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue hemorrhagic fever, management focuses on careful fluid management and close observation during the critical phase to prevent or manage complications such as shock. Platelet transfusions are not routinely given based solely on low counts but are reserved for cases of significant clinical bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Note - There is no correlation between bleeding manifestation and platelet count.

 

Reference - Dengue Case management for Clinicians- CDC

questions.text: Deep y descent in Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) is seen in all of the following conditions except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac Tamponade

 

Deep y descent in JVP (Jugular venous pressure) is a characteristic finding in several conditions that affect the filling of the right ventricle. These conditions include constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Cardiac tamponade, as it is associated with a blunted y descent in JVP rather than a deep y descent. In cardiac tamponade, the pericardial fluid accumulation restricts cardiac filling, leading to a decrease in the amplitude of the y descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition can cause a deep y descent due to the stiff ventricular walls allowing rapid passive filling only during early diastole.

 

Option C. Constrictive pericarditis: Similar to restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis also shows a rapid early diastolic filling as the rigid pericardium constricts ventricular filling in late diastole, leading to a pronounced y descent.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: In tricuspid regurgitation, right atrial emptying occurs without the normal resistance posed by a competent tricuspid valve, often resulting in a prominent y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the presence of fluid in the pericardial space restricts all phases of cardiac filling, leading to a blunted or absent y descent, differentiating it from conditions where a deep y descent is observed.

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate


Calcium oxalate crystals are typically bipyramidal or envelope-shaped. These crystals are common in various conditions, including hyperoxaluria and ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Calcium phosphate:  crystals form asymmetric rosettes.

 

Option C. Uric acid:  crystals are rhomboid forming rosettes, polychromatophilic in Polarized Microscope.

 

Option D. Cystine:  crystals are hexagonal, and one of the hardest crystals.

 

Note - Monohydrate crystal – dumbbell shaped

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium oxalate crystals are bipyramidal or envelope-shaped.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

The patient's symptoms, combined with lab findings of anemia, hypercalcemia, elevated total protein, and low albumin, along with osteolytic lesions, are indicative of multiple myeloma. The CRAB criteria (hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, and Bone lesions) support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Metastatic breast cancer can present similarly but usually has a different primary site.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia but not the full CRAB criteria.

 

Option D. Milk Alkali Syndrome causes hypercalcemia and renal impairment but not the protein abnormalities or osteolytic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and bone lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of central cyanosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothermia

 

Central cyanosis occurs when there is a significant amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood, typically due to issues with oxygenation or hemoglobin abnormalities.

 

In contrast, hypothermia leads to peripheral cyanosis, not central cyanosis. In hypothermia, the blood flow is sluggish due to vasoconstriction, particularly in the extremities, which results in a bluish discoloration of the skin. However, the central organs typically remain oxygenated.

 

Other Options:

 

Central cyanosis can be caused by several factors:

 

Option A. Methemoglobinemia: This condition involves the presence of methemoglobin in the blood, which does not carry oxygen effectively, leading to central cyanosis.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Arteriovenous Fistula: This abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the lungs allows blood to bypass the alveoli, leading to poorly oxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation, causing central cyanosis.

 

Option C. High Altitude: At high altitudes, the reduced atmospheric pressure leads to lower oxygen availability, causing hypoxemia and central cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia causes only peripheral cyanosis due to sluggish blood flow, not central cyanosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder, also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune condition characterized by severe, recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and myelitis. The diagnostic criteria for NMO spectrum disorders include specific clinical syndromes.  

 

Focal epilepsy is not a diagnostic criterion for NMO. While seizures can occur in NMOSD due to brain lesions, focal epilepsy itself is not a major diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Area postrema syndrome  is major criteria. This is characterized by intractable nausea, vomiting, or hiccups, which is due to lesions in the area postrema of the brainstem.

 

Option B. Acute myelitis is major criteria. Inflammation of the spinal cord, usually longitudinally extensive (spanning three or more vertebral segments).

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is major criteria. This involves inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss or impairment, often affecting both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

 

Most Common Core Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  2. Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  3. Area postrema syndrome

 

Less Common Clinical Criteria:

 

  1. Acute brainstem syndrome
  2. Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  3. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)

 

Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A- 'a' wave

B- 1st heart sound

C-Rapid filling of ventricles

D- 't' wave
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABDC

 

Following the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization leading to atrial contraction:

 

A- 'a' wave occurs as a result of atrial contraction, pushing blood into the ventricles.

 

B- 1st heart sound is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of ventricular systole.

 

D- 't' wave represents the repolarization of the ventricles, indicating the beginning of ventricular relaxation.

 

C- Rapid filling of ventricles follows as the ventricles relax and the atrioventricular valves open, allowing blood to flow from the higher pressure atria to the relaxed ventricles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical events precede mechanical events in cardiac homeostasis

 

P wave‚Üí Atrial contraction (a wave).

 

QRS‚Üí ventricular contraction (C wave)

 

T wave‚Üí Ventricular relaxation (Early rapid filling (Y descent)

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Clinical/ chap 239

questions.text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. HbA1c >6.5
  2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL
  3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL
  4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care setting generally include the following criteria:

 

2. Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL: A fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher on two separate occasions indicates diabetes. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.

 

3. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL: A random blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL or higher, along with symptoms of diabetes, is sufficient for diagnosis. This test does not require fasting and can be taken at any time.

 

Other Options:

 

1. HbA1c >6.5%: While this test is beneficial for its ability to reflect average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months and does not require fasting, its higher cost and need for more sophisticated laboratory equipment make it less likely to be used at PHCs in India.

 

4. 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar: Part of the Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT), this test is more comprehensive but requires more time and resources, which may not be feasible in all primary care settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial screening tests for diagnosing diabetes in a primary health care (PHC) setting typically include fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL, and random blood sugar >200 mg/dL. These tests are widely accepted and feasible in most PHC settings.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

 

An arterial pH >7.2, however, is not considered a complication of severe malaria. In fact, severe acidosis is defined by an arterial pH of less than 7.25, and it is a sign of severe malaria. Therefore, an arterial pH >7.2 does not indicate severe malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Plasmodium falciparum malaria is a severe form of malaria that can lead to numerous complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines several criteria for severe malaria, many of which are seen in complicated cases of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Option A. Blood glucose <40 mg/dL: Severe hypoglycemia is a known complication of severe malaria, particularly in patients treated with quinine.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine - 5.2: This indicates severe renal impairment. Serum creatinine levels above 3 mg/dL or reduced urine output despite rehydration are markers of severe malaria.

 

Option D. Unarousable coma: Cerebral malaria, which includes unarousable coma or seizures, is one of the most severe complications of Plasmodium falciparum infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:

 

  1. Arterial pH: An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  2. Bicarbonate Levels: A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  3. Base Deficit: A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  4. Hemoglobin: A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  5. Venous Lactate: A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  6. Blood Glucose: A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  7. Creatinine Levels: A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  8. Urine Output: A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except: (INICET NOV 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Iritis, or inflammation of the iris, is not commonly associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). Instead, RA is more commonly linked to other ocular conditions such as episcleritis and scleritis, which affect different parts of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SLE: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus can involve various parts of the eye, including the development of uveitis, which includes iritis.

 

Option B. Ulcerative Colitis: This inflammatory bowel disease is known to have extraintestinal manifestations including uveitis, which encompasses iritis.

 

Option C. Behcet's Disease: This is a multisystem inflammatory disorder that commonly affects the eyes, including the iris, making iritis a typical manifestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis is typically associated with scleral and episcleral inflammation rather than iritis, distinguishing it from other autoimmune conditions like SLE, Ulcerative Colitis, and Behcet's Disease that can present with iritis as a part of their systemic manifestations.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Troponin ‚Äì T

 

Troponin-T is the most sensitive and specific biomarker available for diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI) within the early hours of symptom onset. It begins to rise within 3-4 hours of myocardial damage, peaks at around 12-48 hours, and remains elevated for up to 7-10 days, making it highly useful for early diagnosis and detection of recent heart damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LDH: it is a less specific enzyme that may be elevated in many types of tissue damage and is not ideal for early diagnosis of MI.

 

Option C. CKMB: it rises within 4-8 hours of myocardial injury, making it less useful than Troponin-T in the very early stages post-symptom onset.

 

Option D. BNP: it is primarily used to assess heart failure and is not a primary marker for acute myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Rise by >20%of troponin is used for diagnosis of Reinfarction

 

Newer biomarkers: HFABP, miRNA1,21,33

 

Reference - (Cardiology/Biomarkers, MI)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

The first-line drugs for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are typically Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs), which include sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate. These drugs are considered core therapies and are often used together in what is known as "triple therapy."

 

Sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate are highly effective and commonly used in the treatment of RA. They form the backbone of conventional synthetic DMARDs (csDMARDs).

 

Azathioprine, on the other hand, is not a first-line drug for RA management. While it is used in some autoimmune conditions, it is not as effective for RA as the other mentioned drugs. Its efficacy is lower, and it is not commonly included in the standard RA treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulfasalazine: This drug is a part of the core therapies for RA and is commonly used as a first-line treatment. It is known for its effectiveness and is often used in combination with other DMARDs.

 

Option B. Hydroxychloroquine: Another key first-line drug for RA, hydroxychloroquine is widely used due to its efficacy and relatively favorable safety profile. It is often part of the triple therapy regimen.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone of RA treatment and is usually the first drug prescribed. It is highly effective and forms the basis of most RA treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

 

Note -

 

  • Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Additional Information:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The patient's ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia. This type of tachycardia, in a stable patient, is initially managed with vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage or the Valsalva maneuver. These maneuvers aim to increase parasympathetic tone and slow conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. If vagal maneuvers are ineffective or not feasible, the next step is to administer an AV nodal blocker.

 

Adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia. It works by transiently blocking the AV node, thereby interrupting the re-entrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia. The initial dose of adenosine is 6 mg administered rapidly IV push, followed by a 10 ml saline flush. If the tachycardia persists, additional doses of 12 mg may be given, with a maximum cumulative dose of 30 mg. Adenosine has a very short half-life of approximately 8 to 10 seconds, necessitating rapid (IV push) administration and immediate follow-up with normal saline to ensure efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for the treatment of various types of arrhythmias, including wide complex tachycardias (regular and monomorphic rhythm).

 

Option B. DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion is used in cases of hemodynamic instability or when pharmacological treatment fails. It is not the first-line treatment for a stable patient presenting with regular narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can be used to manage atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm, because in that case adenosine is contraindicated).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

Inhalational of anthrax spores (<5 microns) are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, carried to local mediastinal lymph nodes releasing toxins causing hemorrhagic mediastinitis

 

It is category A bioterrorism agent along with plague, botulism

 

Treatment recommended with IV antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin+Clindamycin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical pneumonia occurs in Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Legionella pneumonia causing interstitial infiltrates

 

Option B. Lung abscess is seen as complication of infection with anaerobes, complication of pneumonia, atypical organisms like burkholderia, Infective endocarditis with septic embolism

 

Option D. Bronchopneumonia occurs due to pneumococcus, H.influenza etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the hallmark presentation of inhalational anthrax, indicating a severe systemic infection that requires immediate medical attention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Awareness of this presentation is crucial, particularly in contexts involving potential exposure to anthrax spores, such as bioterrorism.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

choices.text: Start ART if CD4 <200
Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks
Start ATT and ART simultaneously

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks


In HIV patients with tuberculosis (TB), it is crucial to start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first to reduce the mycobacterial load before initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART). This approach helps to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), a life-threatening condition due to massive cytokine response triggered by a rapid increase in CD4 count., which can occur if ART is started too early. The general recommendation is to start ART by 2 weeks -2 months, after ATT initiation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Starting ART only if CD4 <200: does not address the immediate need for TB treatment.

 

Option B. Starting ART before ATT: can lead to IRIS.

 

Option D. Starting both therapies simultaneously:  increases the risk of IRIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with TB, start ATT first and then initiate ART after 2 weeks-2 months duration.

choices.text: First degree of heart block

questions.text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild MS.

 

Loud S1 can be heard in mild MS also because loud S1 does not depend on severity of MS.

 

Loud S1 is one of the auscultatory hallmarks of MS, however it can be attenuated in a variety of conditions:

 

  • Associated MR
  • Long PR (first degree heart block)
  • CCF
  • Severe AR- regurgitant jet may impinge on AML
  • Calcified valve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Here, the prolonged PR interval delays the closure of the mitral valve relative to ventricular contraction, often softening or eliminating the loud S1.

 

Option B. AR (Aortic Regurgitation): The regurgitant flow in aortic regurgitation can prevent the mitral valve leaflets from closing tightly and sharply, thus softening the S1.

 

Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leads to stiffening of the leaflets, which inhibits their rapid movement and thus reduces the intensity of S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically present unless there is an associated condition that affects the mobility or timing of the mitral valve leaflet closure, such as calcification, regurgitation in other valves, or disturbances in electrical conduction that affect heart rhythm

questions.text: Patient affected with acute hepatitis B infection has currently come for follow up. Identify the serological marker marked in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc Ab

 

Anti Hbc Ab are produced against Hepatitis B infection. IgM is produced early and IgG later. Production of antibodies(A) is seen to correspond to gradual reduction of surface, envelop antigens.

 

 

Person recovering from acute infection may have negative anti HbS levels with low HbsAg levels. This is called window period where there is a lag between development of antiHbS and HbsAg levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBe Ab: These antibodies against the hepatitis B e antigen generally signify lower levels of viral replication. They are not represented at the marked point in the graph.

 

Option C. Anti-HBs Ab: These antibodies indicate recovery and immunity and typically appear after the disappearance of HBsAg, which occurs later than the timeframe shown for the marked serological marker.

 

Option D. HBsAg: This is the earliest detectable viral antigen to appear in the blood following infection but declines as Anti-HBc Ab and later Anti-HBs appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBc antibodies are crucial in diagnosing hepatitis B infection, as they appear early after exposure and persist throughout the infection. They are typically seen during the "window period" when HBsAg starts to wane and before Anti-HBs becomes detectable, indicating the body's initial immune response to the infection.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Hepatology/Viral hepatitis/ chap 339/

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

 

When localizing lesions in the spinal cord, it is crucial to understand how different tracts and their associated functions are affected:

 

  1. Corticospinal Tract: Damage to this tract results in ipsilateral hemiparesis (weakness) below the level of the lesion. This is because the corticospinal tract crosses over (decussates) at the medulla, above the spinal cord. Therefore, damage at the spinal cord level affects the same side of the body.
  2. Posterior Column: Damage here leads to ipsilateral loss of light touch, vibration, proprioception, and pressure. Similar to the corticospinal tract, the posterior column pathways decussate above the spinal cord.
  3. Spinothalamic Tract: This tract, responsible for pain and temperature sensation, crosses at the level of the spinal cord itself. Damage to the spinothalamic tract results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Given these pathways, contralateral hemiplegia suggests a lesion above the spinal cord, typically above the pyramidal decussation in the brainstem or higher. Therefore, it does not help in localizing lesions within the spinal cord itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fasciculation at the level of lesion: Fasciculations are a sign of lower motor neuron involvement, which can occur at the level of the spinal cord lesion due to damage to the anterior horn cells. This helps in localizing the lesion.

 

Option C. Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion: The presence of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs can be indicative of a spinal cord lesion. UMN signs (such as spasticity and hyperreflexia) occur below the lesion, while LMN signs (such as fasciculations and muscle atrophy) occur at the level of the lesion.

 

Option D. Bladder involvement: Bladder and bowel dysfunction are common in transverse spinal cord lesions. This is due to the involvement of the autonomic pathways that control these functions, helping to localize the lesion within the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contralateral hemiplegia indicates a lesion above the spinal cord, specifically above the level of pyramidal decussation.

choices.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition
Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

 

Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. It is characterized by a patchy distribution of inflammation, which is often transmural (affecting the entire thickness of the bowel wall). Skeletions, also known as skip lesions, are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease, where areas of inflamed tissue are interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease typically involves transmural inflammation, meaning it affects all layers of the bowel wall. On the other hand, ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that is limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition: While there are genetic factors associated with IBD, such as mutations in the NOD2/CARD15 gene linked to Crohn's disease, the overall genetic predisposition is not considered strong. Environmental factors play a more significant role in the development of IBD.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment: This statement is incorrect. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and is not curable by surgical resection. Surgery can help manage symptoms and complications but does not cure the disease. Ulcerative colitis, however, can be cured by surgical removal of the colon and rectum (total proctocolectomy).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all the following conditions except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal Disorders

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by the accumulation of acids in the body, which are not accompanied by an increase in other measured anions, thus increasing the anion gap. This condition typically involves a decrease in bicarbonate as the body tries to buffer the excess hydrogen ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactic Acidosis: This condition occurs when lactate levels increase in the bloodstream during tissue hypoxia, commonly seen in shock or severe dehydration, and results in HAGMA.

 

Option C. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: In DKA, the body produces high levels of blood acids called ketones, which lead to HAGMA.

 

Option D. Salicylate Poisoning: In salicylate toxicity, especially at higher doses, metabolic acidosis occurs due to uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation, leading to HAGMA. Initially, salicylate stimulates the respiratory center causing a respiratory alkalosis, which can be followed by metabolic acidosis at higher doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal disorders typically cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) due to an inability to excrete acid or conserve bicarbonate, rather than high anion gap acidosis seen in conditions like lactic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis, and salicylate poisoning.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin‚Äôs lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin‚Äôs lymphoma.

choices.text: Rewarming is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A soldier operating in Siachen Glacier presents with numbness of his legs. Incorrect regarding the image given: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Analgesics are contraindicated

 

The patient described is likely suffering from frostbite, given the environmental conditions and symptoms of numbness and the visual sign of erythema on the toes. Frostbite occurs when skin and other tissues freeze due to exposure to extremely cold temperatures. The treatment and management of frostbite are critical to prevent long-term damage.

 

Analgesics are contraindicated: This is incorrect. Analgesics, especially opiate analgesics, are crucial during the rewarming process because it is extremely painful. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should be avoided due to their potential to cause further vasoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rewarming is the treatment of choice: This is correct. The first line of treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming in a water bath at 37-39¬∞C (98.6-102.2¬∞F). This helps to restore blood flow and minimize tissue damage.

 

Option C. Thrombolytics can be used: This is correct. In cases where frostbite is severe and the patient presents within 24 hours, thrombolytic therapy may be considered to restore blood flow and prevent tissue death. MR angiography can help assess the need for thrombolytics.

 

Option D. Amputation in severe cases: This is correct. In severe frostbite cases, where there is significant tissue necrosis, amputation may be necessary. This is typically decided based on a bone scan if the patient presents more than 24 hours after the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For frostbite treatment, rewarming is essential, analgesics are indicated due to the pain associated with rewarming, thrombolytics can be used within 24 hours of injury, and amputation may be necessary in severe cases.

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

This is a case of peripheral neuropathy that occurs in ATT therapy due to isoniazid (INH)

 

To treat this – Pyridoxine 10-25mg/day should be added to regimen.

 

High risk patients for peripheral neuropathy include- malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetes, HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: While important for nervous system function, thiamine is not typically depleted by INH therapy.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Not directly related to the neurological side effects of INH.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Though important for nerve health, it is not the primary vitamin depleted by INH therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
