Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

choices.text: 1 & 3; a, c, d
2 & 4; b, c, e
1 & 3; a, d
2 & 4; b, e

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

Clinical findings

 

a. Pulsus bisferiens

b. Pulsus alternans

c. Ejection systolic murmur

d. Murmur increases on standing

e. Murmur decreases on standing

 

Management

 

1. Beta-blockers are given

2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated

3. ICD is indicated

4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3; a, c, d

 

The echocardiography findings and symptoms are indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, due to the thickening of the heart muscle, there is a dynamic obstruction to blood flow, often worsening with decreased preload, such as when standing.

 

  • Pulsus bisferiens (a) is commonly observed in conditions like HCM, where there are two distinct peaks in arterial pulse per cardiac cycle due to the dynamic obstruction.
  • Ejection systolic murmur (c) is typical in HCM and is due to the obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • Murmur increases on standing (d) in HCM due to increased obstruction with reduced venous return.

 

Regarding management:

 

  • Beta-blockers (1) are typically used in HCM to manage symptoms and reduce heart rate, thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and the degree of obstruction.
  • ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) (3) is recommended in patients with HCM who are at high risk of sudden cardiac death.

ICD indicated for all patients with ≥1 risk factor for SCD or HCM-AF score >6%

 

MAVACAMTEN is recently approved drug which modulates b-myosin heavy chain (↓Bridging & Inotropy) & reduces the need for ablation by 80% in long term

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This is incorrect as it suggests that beta-blockers are contraindicated and includes "murmur decreases on standing," which is not characteristic of HCM. Pulsus alternans (b), indicative of severe heart failure, is not typical in HCM without heart failure.

 

Option C. It misses the key management and diagnostic features by excluding the ejection systolic murmur, which is a significant finding in HCM.

 

Option D. This incorrectly includes beta-blockers as contraindicated and excludes the key symptom of an ejection systolic murmur. It also incorrectly suggests that ICD is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key Points:

 

  • All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Test for ANCA


The clinical presentation of ENT involvement, lung nodules with cavitations, and renal failure suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The ANCA (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) test is a useful diagnostic tool for GPA.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Biopsy to show granulomas is useful but more invasive.

 

Option C. AFB staining of sputum is for TB, not GPA.

 

Option D. BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage):  is not specific for diagnosing GPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected GPA, the ANCA test is the most useful initial investigation.

questions.text: A Patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160bpm. His BP is 96/68mmHg. What is the next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid sinus massage.

 

Above ECG findings ‚Äì narrow complex tachycardia without P waves with clinical finding of sudden onset palpitations suggest AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

 

Next best step in management will be carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal maneuver).

 

Vagal maneuvers can terminate an approximate 10-20% of AVNRT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenosine: Used if vagal maneuver fail, adenosine is the drug of choice because it can temporarily block AV node conduction and terminate reentrant tachycardias.

 

Option C. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are another pharmacological option if adenosine fails, used to slow the heart rate and control the symptoms.

 

Option D. Defibrillator: Not appropriate in this scenario as the patient is hemodynamically stable (SBP >90 mmHg) and the tachycardia does not pose an immediate threat to life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carotid sinus massage is the first-line intervention for clinically stable patients presenting with AVNRT, potentially stopping the arrhythmia without the need for drug intervention.

questions.text: A person presents to the hospital with fever and chills. Fever profile is ordered and is found to be negative for malaria and dengue. RK-39 test is found to be positive. What is the treatment of choice? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

 

The RK-39 test is used to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis, which is also known as kala-azar. Visceral leishmaniasis is caused by the Leishmania parasite and is transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. The test detects antibodies against the RK-39 antigen, which is a marker for this disease.

 

In India, the first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis is Amphotericin B. This drug is effective in treating the disease and is preferred due to its ability to clear the infection. While other treatments like sodium stibogluconate are available, Amphotericin B is the standard treatment due to its efficacy and safety profile in the Indian context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: This is an antifungal medication used to treat dermatophyte infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is not effective against parasitic infections like leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Dapsone: This drug is primarily used to treat leprosy and certain types of dermatitis. It is not used for treating leishmaniasis.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: This medication is used for the treatment of malaria, rheumatoid arthritis, and lupus erythematosus. It is not effective against leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RK-39 test is used to diagnose visceral leishmaniasis, and the treatment of choice for visceral leishmaniasis in India is Amphotericin B

questions.text: Identify the clinical diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plexiform neurofibromatosis

 

Plexiform neurofibroma is seen in patients with NF1 commonly in the craniomaxillofacial region. Malignant transformation to MPNST (Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor) occurs in 3-16% patients and is the cause of mortality.

 

The mass typically appears as a "bag of worms" due to the involvement of multiple nerve branches.

 

Treatment is mainly surgical resection of the tumor

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve palsy: This condition typically presents with asymmetrical facial movement and weakness but does not cause mass-like growths.

 

Option B. Masticator space abscess: Characterized by swelling and pain, usually due to an infection, which would not cause the extensive, benign proliferative growth seen in the image.

 

Option D. Fibrous dysplasia: While it can cause bone deformity and asymmetry, it does not manifest as a soft, extensive mass typically seen in neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plexiform neurofibromatosis should be suspected in patients with extensive, soft, non-tender, and irregularly contoured masses along nerve pathways, particularly in those known to have or suspected of having NF1. Surgical resection can be considered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons, though complete removal is often challenging due to the nature of the growth

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of >180/95 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

An early diastolic murmur in the right 2nd intercostal space is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely to be associated with the above findings.

 

BP difference between arms is classical due to blood jet projected towards right brachiocephalic artery, but the murmur of AR is very rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coarctation of the Aorta: Can sometimes show differences in arm blood pressures, especially if the coarctation is proximal to the left subclavian artery. It is also associated with a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to AR.

 

Option C. Takayasu Arteritis: Known for causing vascular inflammation leading to stenoses, which can result in differing blood pressures in the arms. About 25% of patients may also have AR.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: Typically presents with differential blood pressure between arms and can rapidly lead to AR due to involvement of the aortic root.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While differential arm blood pressure can suggest several cardiovascular anomalies, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely among the options given to be associated with these findings, especially concerning the presence of a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia 

 

Hyperkalemia, characterized by elevated potassium levels in the blood, is particularly dangerous in CKD due to its direct impact on cardiac function. High potassium levels can disrupt normal heart rhythms, potentially leading to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased GFR: While it indicates the progression of CKD and reduced kidney function, it does not pose immediate life-threatening risks like hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Increased creatinine: Indicates kidney dysfunction but is a marker rather than a direct cause of severe clinical consequences.

 

Option D. Proteinuria: Signifies kidney damage; however, it is more of a prognostic indicator rather than an acute life-threatening condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion. She could be best managed by? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin with heparin

 

The description of diffuse symmetric TWI without ST elevations is consistent with NSTEMI which is characterized by subtotal platelet-rich thrombosis + distal phasic embolization. NSTEMI treated with DAPT+LMWH followed by CAG for risk stratification

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCI is treatment of choice for STEMI.

 

Option B. Arrhythmia prophylaxis is not the definitive best management strategy

 

Option C. Thrombolysis/Fibrinolytics have no role in the management of NSTEMI

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/ACS/Chap 277

questions.text: 50 yr old gentleman presented with progressive abdominal distension with shifting dullness on examination and dilated veins on lateral chest wall. Ascitic fluid analysis given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Budd-Chiari syndrome

 

Presence of lateral dilated veins with high SAAG, low protein suggests Late Budd-Chiari syndrome.

 

SAAG=Serum albumin- Ascitic Albumin = 2g/dl

 

Interpretation

 

  • ‚â•1.1: Portal Hypertension (Transudate)
  • <1.1: Exudate

 

Ascitic fluid protein helps identify sinusoidal vs non-sinusoidal causes

 

  • Ascitic fluid protein >2.5 = non-sinusoidal  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congestive Heart Failure: Typically presents with high SAAG and high protein content in the ascitic fluid.

 

Option C. Cirrhosis: While cirrhosis can also present with high SAAG, it usually shows low protein content in the ascitic fluid, which aligns with this case, but the presence of dilated veins specific to Budd-Chiari provides a more accurate diagnosis.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous peritonitis typically presents with a low SAAG and high protein content, which is inconsistent with the findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Hepatology/ascites

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5yrs back. His ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for patient? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC Cardioversion.

 

The given ECG shows wide QRS complex with no P wave suggesting the diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia. Clinical features of exercise intolerance and the presence of ischemic heart disease also support the diagnosis of VT. Since patient hemodynamically unstable, next best step is DC Cardioversion. For stable patients, amiodarone is given intravenously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine and D. Lidocaine: These are antiarrhythmic drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias but are less appropriate in acute, hemodynamically unstable VT where immediate cardioversion is preferred.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Typically used for heart rate control in atrial fibrillation and not suitable for acute VT, especially in the context of hemodynamic instability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with ventricular tachycardia and signs of hemodynamic instability, DC Cardioversion is the recommended treatment to quickly restore normal heart rhythm. Pharmacological treatments like amiodarone may be considered post-cardioversion for rhythm stabilization in stable patients.

questions.text:
During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

 

  1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge
  2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia
  3. Watch for Headache and nasal discharge
  4. Monitor glucose levels
  5. Watch for Sinusitis-like symptoms
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4 and 5

 

Discharging a COVID-19 patient involves providing instructions for monitoring ongoing or potential symptoms and managing side effects of treatments such as steroids and remdesivir.

 

3. Watch for headache and nasal discharge: These symptoms can be part of the post-COVID syndrome or could indicate secondary infections like sinusitis, especially after treatment that might suppress the immune system.

 

4. Monitor glucose levels: Steroids, often used in the treatment of severe COVID-19, can elevate blood glucose levels. It‚Äôs crucial for patients, especially those with pre-existing diabetes or those who experienced high glucose levels during treatment, to monitor their levels after discharge.

 

5. Watch for sinusitis-like symptoms: As with headache and nasal discharge, symptoms like those of sinusitis might suggest secondary infections, which are important to monitor given the use of immunomodulating treatments like steroids.

 

Other Options:
 

1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge: Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge is not required as per updated guidelines. Repeat RT-PCR at 7 days of discharge was initially suggested, but later on removed from the guideline. 
 

2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia: Watch for the persistence of Anosmia is a common symptom (Anosmia can persist for weeks together) but, not matching with the options (actual answer should be 2,3,4, and 5).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients recovering from COVID-19 should monitor for symptoms of headache and nasal discharge, glucose levels due to steroid use, and sinusitis-like symptoms which could indicate secondary infections like mucormycosis.

choices.text: Complete transection of spinal cord
Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch
Contralateral loss of pain & temperature

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete transection of spinal cord

 

A complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome. A complete transection would result in loss of all motor and sensory functions below the level of the injury on both sides of the body, which is different from the hemisection seen in Brown-Séquard syndrome.

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome results from a hemisection or partial lesion of the spinal cord, typically affecting one half. This syndrome is characterized by a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the disruption of different spinal cord tracts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch: This occurs because the posterior columns (dorsal columns) are affected, leading to loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch on the same side as the lesion.

 

Option C. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature: This results from the damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses to the opposite side of the spinal cord. Therefore, pain and temperature sensations are lost on the side opposite to the lesion.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral loss of proprioception: Like the loss of vibration and touch, proprioception is also affected ipsilaterally due to involvement of the posterior columns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of vibration, touch, and proprioception, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of this syndrome

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV MgSO4

 

The ECG displays characteristics consistent with Torsades de Pointes (Tdp), which is identified by its distinctive polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and a prolonged QT interval. In the setting of pre-eclampsia, magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is not only used for seizure prophylaxis but also effectively treats Torsades de Pointes by stabilizing the cardiac membrane and correcting magnesium deficiency, a common trigger for this arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV calcium: Used for treating hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia-induced cardiac toxicity, not directly effective for Torsades de Pointes.

 

Option B. DC Shock: Indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with Tdp or other life-threatening arrhythmias, which does not apply here as the patient's vitals are stable.

 

Option D. Synchronized cardioversion: Typically used for managing ventricular tachycardia with a pulse or superventricular tachycardia, but not the first-line for Torsades de Pointes in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable pregnant patient displaying Torsades de Pointes, especially in the context of pre-eclampsia, IV magnesium sulfate is the recommended treatment. It helps in both controlling the arrhythmia and providing prophylaxis against eclamptic seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

CMV is most common infection occurring after transplant. Risk depends on induction agent and seropositivity status. Minimal risk for D-/R-(Donor, recipient negative). Highest risk of reactivation in D-/R+ and patients who received anti-lymphocyte therapy. Prophylaxis is given pre-emptively if periodic CMV-DNA PCR are >500 copies/ml with Valgan/ Foscarnet/Cidofovir. Letermovir has no hepato/nephrotoxicity (Safest)

 

D-/R- patients should receive leucodepleted blood products to minimise transmission of CMV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EBV infection occurs in 1-2% of post-transplant patients and responds well to acyclovir prophylaxis

 

Option C. VZV reactivation can occur at any point post-transplant

 

Option D. HSV occurs within 1-month post-transplant in the absence of acyclovir prophylaxis Nephrology/infectious diseases/post-transplant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent and clinically significant viral infection in the post-solid organ transplant setting in India, necessitating targeted prophylaxis and monitoring protocols to mitigate its risks.

 

Reference - Critical Care Nephrology /Chapter 95

questions.text: A patient with ascites is found to have SAAG ‚â• 1.1. All of the following causes except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TB peritonitis

 

The Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is calculated to differentiate between ascites caused by portal hypertension (high SAAG ‚â• 1.1) and ascites caused by other reasons (low SAAG < 1.1). A SAAG value ‚â• 1.1 indicates that the ascites is likely due to issues related to portal hypertension, such as cirrhosis, liver failure, or metastasis to the liver, which can also cause portal hypertension. Tuberculosis peritonitis, however, typically presents with a SAAG lower than 1.1 because it is not associated with portal hypertension but rather with peritoneal inflammation and capillary leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Directly associated with portal hypertension and commonly results in a SAAG ‚â• 1.1.

 

Option B. Liver failure: Often leads to portal hypertension, causing a high SAAG.

 

Option C. Metastasis to liver: Can impede hepatic blood flow and increase portal pressure, also leading to a high SAAG.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Arterial pH
  2. Venous pH
  3. Venous pO2
  4. Venous pCO2
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Arterial pH is the gold standard for acid-base analysis as it directly measures the hydrogen ion concentration in arterial blood, providing a precise assessment of the patient's acid-base status. Venous pH and venous pCO2 can also provide reliable information about the patient’s acid-base status and are often used in clinical settings where arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is not feasible.

 

1. Arterial pH and 2. Venous pH:  Arterial pH: This is the most accurate method for assessing acid-base balance. Arterial pH varies by only 0.03 to 0.05 from venous pH. To estimate arterial pH from venous pH, add 0.03 to 0.05.

 

4. Venous pCO2: To estimate arterial pCO2 (PaCO2) from venous pCO2, subtract 5 from venous pCO2.

 

Venous pH and venous pCO2 can be used in some situations to predict arterial values.

 

Other Options:
 

3. Venous pO2 is not useful for determining acid-base imbalance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial pH, venous pH, and venous pCO2 are used to determine acid-base imbalances.

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID health centre? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A. Respiratory rate of 25/min

B. SpO2 93%

C. Multiple comorbidities

D. Age
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A, B, C & D only

 

A & B Respiratory rate of 25/min and SpO2 93% : Both of these values are indicative of potential respiratory compromise, which is concerning in a COVID-19 patient. These values suggest the need for closer monitoring and possible oxygen supplementation.

 

C. Multiple comorbidities: Patients with multiple comorbidities are at a higher risk of severe disease and complications from COVID-19, warranting admission for close monitoring and treatment.

 

D. Age: Age is a known risk factor for severity and complications in COVID-19. Older patients, like the 60-year-old man in the scenario, generally have poorer outcomes and may benefit from hospital care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a COVID-19 patient for hospital admission, consider clinical signs of respiratory distress, overall oxygen saturation, presence of comorbidities, and age due to their significant impacts on disease severity and outcome.

questions.text: The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is effectively treated with Doxycycline, which is considered the first-line treatment. Doxycycline is administered at a dosage of 100 mg twice daily for 7 to 14 days. It disrupts protein synthesis in the bacterium, which is crucial for its effectiveness against this intracellular pathogen.

 

In pregnancy/children- Azithromycin/ chloramphenicol preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: While it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, it is not the preferred treatment for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Chloramphenicol: This is an alternative treatment option but is generally reserved for cases where doxycycline or azithromycin cannot be used.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a suitable alternative, especially in special populations such as pregnant women and children, where doxycycline is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxycycline is the first-choice medication for treating scrub typhus in adults and non-pregnant women, offering effective relief and eradication of the pathogen when taken for the recommended duration.

choices.text: Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's chorea

 

Huntington's chorea is characterized by hyperkinetic movements such as chorea but does not typically present with hypokinetic movements.

 

Huntington's chorea presents with a classic triad of abnormal movements (chorea), dementia, and psychiatric manifestations. It also has a strong family history due to its inherited nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's disease shows both tremors (hyperkinetic) and bradykinesia (hypokinetic).

 

Option B. Wilson's disease:  Wilson's disease can present with a combination of movement disorders.

 

Option C. Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation:  Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation also shows mixed movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:


Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mineralocorticoids

 

After a trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, the pituitary gland's ability to produce several hormones including ACTH, TSH, FSH, and LH can be impaired. The lack of ACTH typically necessitates glucocorticoid replacement, but not mineralocorticoid supplementation. This is because the regulation of mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone) is mainly via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which operates independently of the pituitary gland. Aldosterone secretion is primarily controlled by plasma potassium levels and the RAAS, not ACTH, although ACTH can have a stimulatory effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids: Low dose steroid supplementation is required as they are ACTH dependent.

 

Option C. Thyroid hormones: Necessary due to diminished TSH, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion. LT4 supplementation targeting T4 levels is required.

 

Option D. Estradiol: While gonadotropin supplementation post-pituitary surgery can be complex, replacement might be necessary due to the absence of FSH and LH, affecting estrogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Post-hypophysectomy, patients often require supplementation of several hormones, including glucocorticoids and thyroid hormones, due to impaired pituitary function. However, mineralocorticoid supplementation is typically not needed as aldosterone secretion is primarily regulated by the RAAS system, independent of pituitary control.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Chapter 379/

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. Chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Co-trimoxazole only

 

In a patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm presenting with symptoms such as cough and fever, but with a normal chest x-ray, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a likely diagnosis. PCP is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients, especially when the CD4 count is below 200 cells/cu.mm.

 

The treatment of choice for PCP is co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole). It is essential to start treatment empirically in suspected cases of PCP because delayed treatment can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. The dose of co-trimoxazole is typically higher for treating PCP than for prophylaxis.

 

Steroids are indicated in severe cases of PCP to reduce inflammation, specifically if the patient has hypoxemia (PaO2 < 70 mmHg) or an alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient > 35 mmHg. In this scenario, there is no data indicating severe disease, so co-trimoxazole alone is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin: This combination is used for bacterial pneumonia, not PCP. Given the normal chest x-ray and the patient's clinical presentation, bacterial pneumonia is less likely.

 

Option B. Co-trimoxazole + steroids: Steroids are added in severe cases of PCP. However, there is no evidence in this case of severe hypoxemia or an increased A-a gradient to justify the use of steroids along with co-trimoxazole.

 

Option D. Antitubercular treatment: There is no indication from the clinical presentation or the normal chest x-ray that the patient has tuberculosis. Antitubercular treatment is therefore not appropriate in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/cu.mm and presenting with cough and fever but a normal chest x-ray, co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for suspected PCP

 

Note - For a patient with a CD4 count of 200 and lower respiratory tract symptoms:

 

  • PCP Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray is normal or negative.
  • Bacterial Pneumonia: Suspect if the chest X-ray shows consolidation or examination reveals bronchial breath sounds.

questions.text: Diabetic drug that should be stopped immediately with a creatinine of 5.6mg/dl? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin, a commonly prescribed medication for type 2 diabetes, primarily works by reducing hepatic glucose production. It is contraindicated in patients with significant renal impairment due to the risk of lactic acidosis, a potentially life-threatening condition.

 

It is to be stopped if creatinine level >1.5mg/dl in men and >1.4mg/dl in women

 

MOA of metformin- reduces hepatic glucose production.

 

Adverse effects - nausea, diarrhea, lactic acidosis, vit b12 deficiency

 

Contraindications:  serum creatinine 1.5 (in males)/ 1.4(females)

 

GFR<30ml/min, Unstable CHF, Hepatic failure, Acidosis, Hospitalized patients who cannot take anything orally

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Linagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor, which does not require adjustment for kidney disease and is not directly harmful in renal failure.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for cardiovascular conditions including hypertension; not directly affected by renal function in terms of drug safety, though dosing may need adjustment.

 

Option D. Insulin: Often required in higher doses or with careful monitoring in renal impairment due to decreased insulin clearance, but not contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin should be discontinued in patients with a creatinine level above 1.5 mg/dL for men and 1.4 mg/dL for women, or a GFR below 30 mL/min to avoid the risk of lactic acidosis, especially in the context of significant renal impairment.
